headline.main: LOCAL MILITARY MOVEMENTS. SECOND REGIMENT SCOTT LIFE-GUARD.; MR. BRISTOW'S CONCERT. THE SICKLES BRIGADE. PARK BARRACKS. THE REGIMENT AT FORT SCHUYLER. THE SANDY HOOK ESCAMPMENT. docs.lead_paragraph: This Regiment, Col. J. HOBART WARD leaves for East New-York to-day and are going into encampment there. Annexed is a list of the officers: Col. J. H. Hobart Ward; Lieut,-Col. Addison Farnsworth; Adjutant Win. A. Herring; Quartermaster C.J. Murphy; Major J. Decatur Potter; Company A, Capt.

docs.snippet: Gen. BUTLER is yet in Washington. He will not leave for Fort Monroe until about the time the nine regiments from New-York reach the Fort. His Massachusetts troops will precede him.

headline.main: Highly Important News from the Federal Capital.; Concentration of Troops at Fortress Monroe. Gen. Butler to Command the Military Department of Virginia, North Carolina and Tennessee. An Aggressive Movement Expected Immediately.Arrival of the Fourteenth Regiment inWashington.GEN. SICKLES' BRIGADE FOR IMMEDIATE SERVICE Condition of Affairs at Harper's Ferry.Depredations of Rebel Troops in Maryland. Laughable Stampede of theAlexandrians.SECESSION OUTRAGES AT NORFOLK. AFFAIRS AT HARPER'S FERRY. THE CENTRE OF OPERATIONS. ARRIVAL OF SENATOR SUMNER. GEN. SICKLE'S BRIGADE. AFFAIRS AT FORT MONROE. COMFORT OF THE TROOPS. THE GREEN MOUNTAIN BOYS. BREAD FOR THE ARMY. ARRIVAL OF THE FOURTEENTH. CAPTURE OF A SPY. NEW FLAG FOR THE WHITE HOUSE. DISPATCH TO THE ASSOCIATED PRESS.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. BUTLER is yet in Washington. He will not leave for Fort Monroe until about the time the nine regiments from New-York reach the Fort. His Massachusetts troops will precede him.

docs.snippet: Harpers' Monthly is before the public with its customary promptitude. The number for June may be characterized as unusually good, and even above the happy average which this periodical has secured for itself. "What is Best"--a keen and biting paper...
docs.lead_paragraph: Harpers' Monthly is before the public with its customary promptitude. The number for June may be characterized as unusually good, and even above the happy average which this periodical has secured for itself. "What is Best"--a keen and biting paper from the pen of CHARLES NORDHOFF, Esq., is searching as a nor'wester, and equally health-giving.

docs.snippet: --To put a book afloat at the present time would be much like a man's standing on the seashore and endeavoring to make himself heard when the waters were lashed by a violent storm. Publishers and authors are fully conscious of this fact, and act...
docs.lead_paragraph: --To put a book afloat at the present time would be much like a man's standing on the seashore and endeavoring to make himself heard when the waters were lashed by a violent storm. Publishers and authors are fully conscious of this fact, and act accordingly.

docs.snippet: The news from the Federal Capital this morning is not of special importance, excepting as indicating the continued vigor with which the Administration is preparing everything for the great struggle which is now impending.
docs.lead_paragraph: The news from the Federal Capital this morning is not of special importance, excepting as indicating the continued vigor with which the Administration is preparing everything for the great struggle which is now impending.
